statement.text: A suprarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm extends above both renal arteries to involve the visceral aortic segment, including the origins of the celiac axis and/or superior mesenteric artery (SMA). This represents the most complex subtype of abdominal aortic aneurysm, requiring reconstruction of multiple visceral vessels during repair. Suprarenal AAA bridges the gap between standard abdominal aneurysms and type IV thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysms, sharing surgical complexity with the latter while being approached primarily through abdominal incisions.
statement.formal: Suprarenal AAA: Aneurysm extending above both renal arteries to involve the visceral segment (celiac and/or SMA origins), requiring visceral reconstruction and representing transition to thoracoabdominal pathology.

explanation.intuition: Imagine a section of water main that's swollen and damaged not just near the branch points to individual houses (kidneys), but also the major branches feeding entire neighborhoods (intestines, stomach, liver, spleen). Replacing this section means reconnecting all those major branch lines while temporarily shutting off water to critical areas. The complexity increases dramatically with each additional branch that must be managed.
explanation.key_insight: Suprarenal AAA represents the most challenging anatomy within the abdominal aorta because it involves all visceral vessels - celiac, SMA, and renals. The repair requirements approach those of Crawford Extent IV thoracoabdominal aneurysms, with similar visceral ischemia times and reconstruction complexity. Patient selection for open vs endovascular repair requires careful assessment of physiologic reserve and anatomic suitability.
explanation.technical_details: Open repair requires supraceliac or supramesenteric clamping with visceral ischemia involving kidneys, liver, spleen, and intestines simultaneously. All visceral vessels require reconstruction, typically using the 'inclusion' technique with a Carrel patch for close origins or individual reimplantation/bypass for widely separated vessels. Fenestrated and branched EVAR (F/B-EVAR) allows endovascular treatment in suitable anatomy, with fenestrations for aligned vessels (renals) and branches for angulated vessels (SMA, celiac). Off-the-shelf devices for suprarenal anatomy are becoming available, reducing manufacturing delays.

presentation: May present with mesenteric symptoms (chronic mesenteric ischemia) if visceral stenoses present
Higher rupture risk per diameter compared to infrarenal AAA

anatomic_criteria.defining_feature: Aneurysm extends above both renal arteries to involve celiac and/or SMA origins
anatomic_criteria.boundaries: From suprarenal aorta to aortic bifurcation

comparison.pararenal: Involves renal origins, not visceral segment
comparison.Crawford_IV_TAAA: From diaphragm to bifurcation - overlapping definition

diagnosis: Arterial phase imaging to assess visceral vessels
Delayed phase to assess renal excretion

open_repair.approach: Thoracoabdominal or transabdominal with medial visceral rotation
visceral_reconstruction: Individual bypass grafts (beveled graft with branches)
open_repair.outcomes: Higher mortality (8-15%) and morbidity than infrarenal repair

fenestrated_branched_EVAR.planning: Extensive centerline measurements, CT with precise protocols
fenestrated_branched_EVAR.outcomes: Comparable mortality with lower early morbidity, higher reintervention

hybrid_approaches.visceral_debranching: Open bypass to visceral vessels from iliac or infrarenal aorta
hybrid_approaches.followed_by: Standard EVAR with coverage of native visceral origins
hybrid_approaches.indication: High-risk open repair candidates not suitable for F/B-EVAR

definition.@value: Abdominal aortic aneurysm extending above both renal arteries to involve the visceral segment including celiac and/or SMA origins, requiring visceral vessel reconstruction

sources.citation: Society for Vascular Surgery clinical practice guidelines for the management of AAA. J Vasc Surg. 2018;67(1):2-77.e2.
Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy, 10th Edition, Chapter 71-72
European Society for Vascular Surgery (ESVS) 2019 Clinical Practice Guidelines

learning_objectives: Define suprarenal AAA by anatomic criteria involving visceral segment
Understand the relationship between suprarenal AAA and Crawford IV TAAA
Compare visceral reconstruction techniques in open repair
Describe fenestrated and branched EVAR for suprarenal anatomy
Recognize the higher morbidity and mortality of suprarenal repair
clinical_pearls: Suprarenal AAA blurs with Crawford IV TAAA - treatment complexity is similar
Supraceliac clamp creates simultaneous ischemia of kidneys, liver, spleen, and gut
Cold visceral perfusion extends safe ischemia from 30 to 60+ minutes
Off-the-shelf F/B devices are reducing the 6-12 week manufacturing delay
Visceral debranching with standard EVAR offers a hybrid alternative

medicalCode.description: Endovascular repair of visceral aorta with 2 or more visceral artery endoprostheses
